field_paragraph_text.value:
Your mission statement will also be the guide for your decisions. You may come across great opportunities for growth, partnership, or new programs. Use your mission statement to help you decide if it is wise or beneficial for you to pursue such opportunities. Let us look at an example.

  • Cultivate is approached by an American woman who has a passion to bring clean water to villages in India. This woman wants to become a partner. Though we greatly admire this woman’s passion, we see that this clearly falls outside of our mission, and determine that partnership is not a wise option for us to pursue. Our mission is to empower people who are indigenous to the community that they are serving, for us to help a foreigner start a project in a community that she is not from is outside of our mission.

Our mission statement is a clear boundary that helps us make our decisions. Sometimes, opportunities will come your way that fall outside of your mission. At this time, you and your team must determine if this opportunity needs to be turned down, or if you need to change your mission statement to be able to pursue this opportunity. Changing your mission statement is not wrong; however, you do not want to change it so often that your team and your supporters have no clear understanding of what you are doing.
